page.text: Public Hearing and possible motion regarding rezone #13CZ30, 295± acres for the property located at 0, 9524
Horton Road, 3916 Old US 1 Hwy from R-80 W and R-40 W (Wake County) to Planned Unit Development
Conditional Zoning (PUD-CZ) district classification and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment from Rural Density
Residential and Low Density Residential to Low Density Residential. The subject property is identified on Wake
The Planning Board heard this at their March 10, 2014 meeting and recommended approval. Report attached.
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
All property owners and neighborhood associations within three hundred (300) feet of this rezoning have been
295± Acres at Old US 1 and Horton Road
Applicant: Donald and Sharron Lawrence, Edith Lawrence, Billy Rogers, Jr., Gail T. Mooney, and
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
Current Zoning: Wake County R-40W and Wake County R-80W
Proposed Zoning: PUD-CZ (Planned Unit Development-Conditional Zoning)
2030 Land Use Map Current: Low Density Residential & Rural Density Residential
2030 Land Use Map Proposed: Low Density Residential
All outside. Must be annexed prior to approval.
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
Maximum 1.5 units per acre overall. (440 units/295 acres)
Proposed Phases: Six (5 residential and 1 amenity center). Phases have maximum heights, densities,
units and building setbacks. See the PD Plan for details on each phase.
25%- Including Riparian Buffers, Lowland Woodlands, and Perimeter Buffers
See the attached PD Plan for the Architectural Conditions. The conditions not only include the
standard neighborhood architectural conditions but incorporate 5 additional architectural conditions.

text.b: Pedestrian Circulation System and Project Amenities:

page.text: A 10’ wide multi-use trail along major loop streets within the development connecting Old US 1
Unified street fixtures & furniture (street light fixtures and poles, mailboxes, benches,
Street tree planting incorporating both canopy and ornamental understory trees along all
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
Standard streets – 27’ B-B roadway sections on 50’ R/W with sidewalks on one side.
Modified streets - 27’ B-B roadway sections on 60’ R/W with a 10’ wide multi-use trail on one
A junior Olympic size competition swimming pool
Within the proposed open space of Jordan Pointe, a minimum number of three gazebos will be
constructed at vantage points along the off-street trail system.
Along the streetside multi-use trail system, a minimum number of 5 seating areas will be
provided within abutting common area accessible to the trail.
The applicant conducted a neighborhood meeting on September 30, 2013. The report is attached.
The 2030 Land Use Map identifies the proposed site for Rural Density and Low Density Residential.
The applicant is requesting an amendment to the 2030 Land Use Map to Low Density Residential with
the PUD condition that the overall density is not to exceed 1.5 units an acre.
The proposed PUD is consistent with the Apex Transportation Plan and the proposed Apex
Transportation Plan amendment to add a major collector road connecting across the subject property
from Horton Road to the eastern property boundary; future development would be required to
extend the road from the subject property to New Hill Olive Chapel Road.
Apex staff concurs with the applicant providing a major collector road connecting to Horton Road and
stubbing to the eastern property boundary in addition to providing the primary site access on Old US 1 to
allow up to 440 single family homes. Staff recommends future completion of the major collector street
to New Hill Olive Chapel Road by others as part of off site development yet to be determined.
Apex staff concur with all the recommendations in the Traffic Impact Analysis and those are included in
a. 75-foot westbound right turn lane on Old US 1 at Horton Road
b. Traffic signal for the intersection of Old US 1 at New Hill Olive Chapel Road/New Hill Holleman Road
c. 50-foot eastbound left turn lane & 125-foot westbound right turn lane for the site driveway at Old US 1
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
See the attached full summary from Traffic Engineer Russell Dalton, PE.
The proposed Jordan Pointe PD Plan is in compliance with the standards provided in the UDO.

text.b: PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURAL RESOURCES ADVISORY COMMISSION:

page.text: The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Resources Advisory Commission reviewed this project on October
“The first preference of the Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources Advisory Commission is that
the developers of Jordan Pointe pursue a partnership with other developers in the area that will
result in a regional park facility consistent with the Town’s Parks Recreation, Greenways, and Open
Space Master Plan. In the event that such a regional facility/ partnership is not accomplished to the
Town’s satisfaction by the time the first plat is submitted for Jordan Pointe, the developer shall be
required to pay a fee in lieu for the project with the caveat that the Town and developer could elect
to continue seeking a regional park facility at their discretion if sufficient progress is being made
Staff is not opposed to the applicant’s request to amend the 2030 Land Use Map from Rural Density
Residential to Low Density Residential given the PUD-CZ zoning condition limiting density to 1.5 units
per acre. If the 2030 Land Use Map amendment is approved by Town Council, Staff recommends
approval of the Jordan Pointe PD Plan, rezoning #13CZ30 with the conditions as agreed to by the
The Planning Board heard this at their March 10, 2014 meeting and unanimously recommended
approval of the 2030 Land Use Map Amendment and rezone #13CZ30.

text.b: ANALYSIS STATEMENT OF THE REASONABLENESS OF THE PROPOSED REZONING:

page.text: This proposed rezoning of PUD-CZ is in keeping with the low density and residential nature of the area
and increased demand for housing in Apex.

text.b: PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT AND CONDITIONAL ZONING STANDARDS:

page.text: The Town Council shall find the PUD-CZ designation demonstrates compliance with the following standards.
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
In return for greater flexibility in site design requirements, Planned Developments (PD) Districts are
expected to deliver exceptional quality community designs that preserve critical environmental resources;
provide high quality community amenities; incorporate creative design in the layout of buildings, Resource
Conservation Area and circulation; ensure compatibility with surrounding land uses and neighborhood
character; provide high quality architecture; and provide greater efficiency in the layout and provision of
roads, utilities, and other infrastructure. The Planned Development (PD) Districts shall not be used as a
means of circumventing the Town’s adopted land development regulations for routine developments.
In approving a Planned Development (PD) Zoning District designation for a PUD-CZ, the Town Council shall
find the PUD-CZ district designation and PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates compliance with the following
The uses proposed to be developed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ are those uses permitted
The uses proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ can be entirely residential, entirely non-
residential, or a mix of residential and non-residential uses. The location of uses
proposed by the PUD-CZ must be shown in the PD Plan with a maximum density for
each type of residential use and a maximum square footage for each type of non-
The dimensional standards in Sec. 5.1.3, Table of Intensity and Dimensional Standards,
Planned Development Districts may be varied in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ. In no case
shall the minimum side setback for single-family and modular residential be less than
five (5) feet. The PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with all other dimensional
standards of the UDO, North Carolina Building Code, and North Carolina Fire Code.
The development proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ encourages cluster and compact
development to the greatest extent possible that is interrelated and linked by
pedestrian ways, bikeways and other transportation systems. At a minimum, the PD
Plan must show sidewalk improvements as required by the Apex Transportation Plan
and the Town of Apex Standard Specifications and Standard Details, and greenway
improvements as required by the Town of Apex Parks, Recreation, Greenways, and
Open Space Plan and the Apex Transportation Plan.
The design of development in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ results in land use patterns that
promote and expand opportunities for walkability, connectivity, public transportation,
and an efficient compact network of streets. Cul-de-sacs shall be avoided unless the
design of the subdivision and the existing or proposed street system in the surrounding
area indicate that a through street is not essential in the location of the proposed cul-
de-sac, or where sensitive environmental areas such as streams, floodplains, and
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
wetlands would be substantially disturbed by making road connections.
The development proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ is compatible with the character
of surrounding land uses and maintains and enhances the value of surrounding
Off-street parking and loading. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with the
standards of Sec. 8.3, Off-Street Parking and Loading, except that variations from these
standards may be permitted if a comprehensive parking and loading plan for the PUD-CZ is
submitted as part of the PD Plan that is determined to be suitable for the PUD-CZ, and generally
consistent with the intent and purpose of the off-street parking and loading standards.
RCA. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with Sec. 8.1.2, Resource
Conservation Area, except that the percentage of RCA required under Sec. 8.1.2 may be
reduced by the Town Council by no more than two (2%) percent.
Landscaping. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with the standards of Sec.
8.2, Landscaping, Buffering and Screening, except that variations from these standards may be
permitted where it is demonstrated that the proposed landscaping sufficiently buffers uses
from each other, ensures compatibility with land uses on surrounding properties, creates
attractive streetscapes and parking areas and is consistent with the character of the area. In no
case shall a buffer be less than one half of the width required by Sec. 8.2 or ten (10) feet in
Signs. Signage in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with Sec. 8.7, Signs,
except that the standards can be varied as follows if a master signage plan is submitted for
review and approval concurrent with the PD plan:
The square footage of all permitted permanent ground and wall signage shall be allowed
to be increased by ten (10%) percent of the calculated allowable square footage.
The names of up to two (2) tenants are allowed per ground sign provided that the name
of the overall development is listed first and is a minimum of fifty (50%) percent larger
Public facilities. The improvements standards and guarantees applicable to the public facilities
that will serve the site shall comply with Article 7: Subdivision.
The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates a safe and adequate on-site transportation
circulation system. The on-site transportation circulation system shall be integrated
with the off-site transportation circulation system of the Town. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ
shall be consistent with the Apex Transportation Plan and the Town of Apex Standard
Specifications and Standard Details and show required right-of-way widths and road
sections. A Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) shall be required per Sec. 13.19.
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates a safe and adequate on-site system of potable
water and wastewater lines that can accommodate the proposed development, and
are efficiently integrated into off-site potable water and wastewater public
improvement plans. The PD Plan shall include a proposed water and wastewater plan.
Adequate off-site facilities for potable water supply, sewage disposal, solid waste
disposal, electrical supply, fire protection and roads shall be planned and programmed
for the development proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ, and the development is
conveniently located in relation to schools and police protection services.
The PD Plan shall demonstrate compliance with the parks and recreation requirements
of Sec. 7.3 Park, Recreation, and Open Space Sites if there is a residential component in
Natural resource and environmental protection. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates
compliance with the current regulatory standards of this Ordinance related to natural resource
and environmental protection in Sec. 6.1 Watershed Protection Overlay District, Sec. 6.2 Flood
Damage Prevention Overlay District, and Sec. 8.1 Resource Conservation.
Storm water management. The PD Plan shall demonstrate that the post-development rate of
on-site storm water discharge from the entire site shall not exceed pre-development levels in
accordance with Sec. 6.1.7 of the UDO.
Phasing. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall include a phasing plan for the development. If
development of the PUD-CZ is proposed to occur in more than one phase, then guarantees
shall be provided that project improvements and amenities that are necessary and desirable for
residents of the project, or that are of benefit to the Town, are constructed with the first phase
of the project, or, if this is not possible, then as early in the project as is technically feasible.
Consistency with 2030 Land Use Map. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates consistency with
the goals and policies established in the Town’s 2030 Land Use.
Complies with the UDO. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates compliance with all other
Jordan Pointe PUD-#13CZ30 and 2030 Land Use Map Amendment
Prepared by: Lauren Simmons, Planner II
The applicant shall propose site-specific standards and conditions that take into account the following
considerations, which are considerations that are relevant to the legislative determination of whether
or not the proposed conditional zoning district rezoning request is in the public interest. These
considerations do not exclude the legislative consideration of any other factor that is relevant to the
1) Consistency with 2030 Land Use Map. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s
appropriateness for its proposed location and consistency with the purposes, goals, objectives, and
policies of the 2030 Land Use Map.
2) Compatibility. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s appropriateness for its proposed
location and compatibility with the character of surrounding land uses.
3) Zoning district supplemental standards. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s
compliance with Sec 4.4, Supplemental Standards, if applicable.
4) Design minimizes adverse impact. The design of the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s
minimization of adverse effects, including visual impact of the proposed use on adjacent lands; and
avoidance of significant adverse impacts on surrounding lands regarding trash, traffic, service delivery,
parking and loading, odors, noise, glare, and vibration and not create a nuisance.
5) Design minimizes environmental impact. The proposed Conditional Zoning District use’s minimization
of environmental impacts and protection from significant deterioration of water and air resources,
wildlife habitat, scenic resources, and other natural resources.
6) Impact on public facilities. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s avoidance of having
adverse impacts on public facilities and services, including roads, potable water and wastewater
facilities, parks, schools, police, fire and EMS facilities.
7) Health, safety, and welfare. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s affect on the health,
safety, or welfare of the residents of the Town or its ETJ.
8) Detrimental to adjacent properties. Whether the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use is
9) Not constitute nuisance or hazard. Whether the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use
constitutes a nuisance or hazard due to traffic impact or noise, or because of the number of persons
who will be using the Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use.
10) Other relevant standards of this Ordinance. Whether the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District

text.i: use complies with all standards imposed on it by all other applicable provisions of this Ordinance for use,

text.b: Staff comments for Lawrence Assemblage (Jordan Pointe) TIA dated

page.text: Please review the following comments and recommendations. You may schedule a
meeting with me and your client to discuss at your convenience.
The subdivision is located on the north side of Old US 1 between New Hill Olive
Chapel Road and Horton Road with frontage on Old US 1 and on Horton Road.
The study includes the stop controlled intersections of Old US 1 at Horton Road
and Old US 1 at New Hill Olive Chapel Road/New Hill Holleman Road.
The TIA assumes 440 single family homes and is anticipated to generate 80 inbound
trips and 238 outbound trips in the a.m. peak hour, 251 inbound trips and 148 outbound
trips in the p.m. peak hour, and 4,104 trips on a typical weekday. The distribution is as
48% of trips to/from the south on New Hill Holleman Road (interchange at US 1)
30% to/from the east on Old US 1 (interchange at NC 540)
20% to/from the north on New Hill Olive Chapel Road with primary intersections at
Olive Chapel Road and at US 64/NC 751
2% to/from the west on Old US 1
Site Access (includes review of layout plan)
There is one point of access along Old US 1 proposed 0.27 miles east of Horton
There are two points of access proposed along Horton Road, one located 0.34
miles north of Old US 1 and the second one located 0.44 miles further north. All
three points are proposed as full movement.
The Horton Road approach to Old US 1 is anticipated to operate with short delays for
The approaches of New Hill Olive Chapel Road and New Hill Holleman Road are
anticipated to operate with long delays under stop control but the intersection is
anticipated to operate at LOS B with a traffic signal in the peak hours for build-out in
All proposed points of access for the site are anticipated to operate with short delays.
The TIA recommends a 75 foot westbound right turn lane on Old US 1 at Horton
Road. Apex staff concurs with the recommendation.
The TIA recommends a traffic signal for the intersection of Old US 1 at New Hill
Olive Chapel Road/New Hill Holleman Road. Apex staff concurs with the
3. The TIA recommends a 50 foot eastbound left turn lane and 125 foot westbound
right turn lane for the site driveway at Old US 1. Apex staff concurs with the
4. The TIA recommends no exclusive turning lanes for the site driveways along

i.b: Apex staff concurs with the recommendation.

page.text: 5. The PUD plan and TIA propose the aforementioned points of access for up to 440
single family homes. Apex staff recommend that the site be limited to 300

i.b: dwelling units until a second point of access along a dedicated public route is
provided to New Hill Olive Chapel Road.

page.text: NCDOT maintains Old US 1, Horton Road, New Hill Olive Chapel Road, and New Hill
Holleman Road. I welcome the opportunity to discuss any recommendations pertaining
to state-maintained roads and encourage discussions with NCDOT as early as possible
prior to review by Town Council.
Old US 1 @ New Hill Olive Chapel
